questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that uses Microsoft Defender for Endpoint.

You plan to perform device discovery and authenticated scans of network devices.

You install and register the network scanner on a device named Device1.

What should you do next?

choices.A: Download and run an onboarding package.
choices.C: Apply for Microsoft Threat Experts – Targeted Attack Notifications.
choices.B: Connect Defender for Endpoint to Microsoft Intune.

discussion.content: I tried to create the policy in my test environment and in the scope I can select all types of groups, shouldn’t it be the e?

I tested this, D is correct.

How to security-enable a MS 365 group: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/canvas-apps/share-app#share-an-app-with-microsoft-365-groups

Once you do that and create an Office app policy(Endpoint Manager - Select Apps > Policies for Office apps > Create > Scope > "This policy configuration applies to users in a specified group") then you CAN select both (mail-enabled and pure) security groups AND security-enabled MS365 groups.

Test it, too, and you will see.
I have tested this, it can be applied to all of them but security needs to be enabled!

Selected Answer: D
Cloud Policy supports Microsoft 365 Groups and Azure AD Security Groups created in or synchronized to Azure AD. The membership type can be either Dynamic or Assigned.


https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-office-policies
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/admincenter/overview-cloud-policy#requirements-for-using-cloud-policy

Selected Answer: D
Both security groups

To which groups can you deploy the policy1?
Seems to be good choose the D option (Group 1 and Group 4 only), both security groups.
Someone can explain why not?

Selected Answer: B
Only security groups

Selected Answer: B
Correct Answer is B

Selected Answer: B
Endpoint Manager - Select Apps > Policies for Office apps > Create - Select security group
Only security groups can be selected, checked on my tenant and no other group was appearing except Security group and Mail enabled Security group

Selected Answer: B
Tested this in my lab. When you are in the scope tab and select a group the portal will tell you: "Search for security group". I wasn't able to add any other types of groups.
Also you can only assign one group per policy.

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that uses Microsoft Defender for Office 365.

The subscription has the default inbound anti-spam policy and a custom Safe Attachments policy.

You need to identify the following information:

• The number of email messages quarantined by zero-hour auto purge (ZAP)
• The number of times users clicked a malicious link in an email message

Which Email & collaboration report should you use? To answer. select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Wrong answers
Microsoft Defender -reports - Email & collaboration reports
Question 1 Mail flow report - Mail flow - ZAP removed
Question 2 URL protection report - Blocked and clicked through

- Mailflow status summary 
- URL Protection Report
Cancel my last, Threat protection will not bring up the relevant data, mail flow rule is the correct answer

I believe question 1 maybe threat protection as 

Use Threat Explorer (and real-time detections) to filter All email events by the value ZAP for the Additional action column.

You can use Mailflow for the following 

Use the Mailflow view in the Mailflow status report to see the number of ZAP-affected messages for the specified date range.

So Mailflow will work for a specific date range however Threat protection would collect all data collected on ZAP

I agree with vanr2000
1: mail flow rule
2: Url Protection report

Both links provided from vanr2000 explain perfectly

Question 1: Mail flow report 

To determine if ZAP moved your message, you have the following options:

Number of messages: Use the Mailflow view in the Mailflow status report to see the number of ZAP-affected messages for the specified date range.
Message details: Use Threat Explorer (and real-time detections) to filter All email events by the value ZAP for the Additional action column.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/zero-hour-auto-purge?view=o365-worldwide

Question 2: Url protection report
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/reports-defender-for-office-365?view=o365-worldwide#view-data-by-url-click-protection-action

Question 1:Threat Protection Status
https://portal.iotap.com/knowledgebase/article/KA-01204/en-us

Question 2: Url protection report
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/reports-defender-for-office-365?view=o365-worldwide#view-data-by-url-click-protection-action

Checked in Lab.
1) Mailflow Status Report
2) URL Protection Report
I believe the answers are flipped

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

Your company has a Microsoft 365 E5 tenant.

Users at the company use the following versions of Microsoft Office:

• Microsoft 365 Apps for enterprise
• Office for the web
• Office 2016
• Office 2019

The company currently uses the following Office file types:

• .docx
• .xlsx
• .doc
• .xls

You plan to use sensitivity labels. You need to identify the following:

• Which versions of Office require an add-in to support the sensitivity labels.
• Which file types support the sensitivity labels.

What should you identify? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
- Office 2016 and Office 2019 only
- .docx and .xlsx

1. Office 2016 & 2019
"This labeling client doesn't support standalone editions of Office, sometimes called "Office Perpetual"

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/sensitivity-labels-versions#sensitivity-label-capabilities-in-word-excel-and-powerpoint

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/sensitivity-labels-office-apps?source=recommendations&view=o365-worldwide#labeling-client-for-desktop-apps

2. Doc, Xls, Docx and Xlsx
"Microsoft Office: The following file types, including 97-2003 file formats and Office Open XML formats for Word, Excel, and PowerPoint:"


https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/information-protection/rms-client/clientv2-admin-guide-file-types

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/sensitivity-labels-office-apps?source=recommendations&view=o365-worldwide#labeling-client-for-desktop-apps

Labeling client for desktop apps
To use sensitivity labels that are built into Office desktop apps for Windows and Mac, you must use a subscription edition of Office. This labeling client doesn't support standalone editions of Office, sometimes called "Office Perpetual".

comments.content:
additionally: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/sensitivity-labels-office-apps?source=recommendations&view=o365-worldwide#office-file-types-supported

Generally, Office apps that have built-in labeling for Word, Excel, and PowerPoint files support the Open XML format (such as .docx and .xlsx) but not the Microsoft Office 97-2003 format (such as .doc and .xls), Open Document Format (such as .odt and .ods), or other formats. When a file type is not supported for built-in labeling, the Sensitivity button is not available in the Office app.

discussion.content: Which versions of Office require an add-in to support the sensitivity labels. - Office 2016 and Office 2019 only

All Office files support sensitivity labels.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/information-protection/rms-client/clientv2-admin-guide-file-types

comments.content: Agreed - To use sensitivity labels that are built into Office desktop apps for Windows and Mac, you must use a subscription edition of Office. This labeling client doesn't support standalone editions of Office, sometimes called "Office Perpetual".

.doc and .xls are older word/excel that don't support sensitivity labels
First answer is wrong and should be Office 2016 and 2019 as subscription based apps support sensitivity labels.
Second answer is correct
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/sensitivity-labels-office-apps?view=o365-worldwide#labeling-client-for-desktop-apps

You are unfortunately wrong, "Generally, Office apps that have built-in labeling for Word, Excel, and PowerPoint files support the Open XML format (such as .docx and .xlsx) but not the Microsoft Office 97-2003 format (such as .doc and .xls), Open Document Format (such as .odt and .ods), or other formats. When a file type is not supported for built-in labeling, the Sensitivity button is not available in the Office app."

Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/sensitivity-labels-office-apps?view=o365-worldwide
